raw_text: But (Chelba and Jelinek, 1998) chooses the lexical heads of the two previous constituents as determined by a shift-reduce parser, and works better than a trigram model
clean_text: But (Chelba and Jelinek, 1998) chooses the lexical heads of the two previous constituents as determined by a shift-reduce parser, and works better than a trigram model.

citing_paper_authors: Stephen, Wan | Mark, Dras | Robert, Dale | Cécile L., Paris
raw_text: Thismarraige of models has been tested in other fields such as speech recognition (Chelba and Jelinek,1998) with success
clean_text: This marraige of models has been tested in other fields such as speech recognition (Chelba and Jelinek, 1998) with success.

raw_text: (Chelba and Jelinek, 1998) combine unlabeled and labeled data for parsing with a view towards language modeling applications
clean_text: (Chelba and Jelinek, 1998) combine unlabeled and labeled data for parsing with a view towards language modeling applications.

raw_text: Aware that the n-gram obscures many linguistically-signi cant distinctions (Chomsky, 1956, section 2.3), many speech researchers (Jelinekand Laerty, 1991) sought to incorporate hierarchical phrase structure into language modeling (see (Stolcke, 1997)) although it was not until the late 1990s that such models were able to signi cantly improve on 3-grams (Chelba and Jelinek, 1998)
clean_text: Aware that the n-gram obscures many linguistically-signi cant distinctions (Chomsky, 1956, section 2.3), many speech researchers (Jelinek and Laerty, 1991) sought to incorporate hierarchical phrase structure into language modeling (see (Stolcke, 1997)) although it was not until the late 1990s that such models were able to signi cantly improve on 3-grams (Chelba and Jelinek, 1998).

raw_text: The language model described by Chelba and Jelinek (1998) similarly conditions on linguistically relevant words by assigning partial phrase structure to the history and percolating headwords
clean_text: The language model described by Chelba and Jelinek (1998) similarly conditions on linguistically relevant words by assigning partial phrase structure to the history and percolating headwords.

raw_text: In this situation, a structured language model (SLM) was proposed byChelba and Jelinek (1998)
clean_text: In this situation, a structured language model (SLM) was proposed by Chelba and Jelinek (1998).

raw_text: Probabilistic context free grammars seem also more suitable than finite state devices for language modeling, and several language models based on these grammars have been recently proposed in the literature; see for in stance (Chelba and Jelinek, 1998), (Charniak, 2001) and (Roark, 2001)

citing_paper_authors: Lane, Schwartz | Chris, Callison-Burch | William, Schuler | Stephen, Wu
raw_text: Chelba and Jelinek (1998) proposed that syntactic structure could be used as an alternative technique in language modeling
clean_text: Chelba and Jelinek (1998) proposed that syntactic structure could be used as an alternative technique in language modeling.

raw_text: As an alternative option to our verb-modifier experiments, structured language models (Chelba and Jelinek, 1998) might be considered to improve clause coherence, until full-featured syntax-based MT models (Yamada and Knight (2002), Eisner (2003), Chiang (2005) among many others )aretested when translating to morphologically rich languages
clean_text: As an alternative option to our verb-modifier experiments, structured language models (Chelba and Jelinek, 1998) might be considered to improve clause coherence, until full-featured syntax-based MT models (Yamada and Knight (2002), Eisner (2003), Chiang (2005) among many others) aretested when translating to morphologically rich languages.

citing_paper_authors: Dharmendra, Kanejiya | Arun, Kumar | Surendra, Prasad
raw_text: In the first type, probability of a word is decided based on a parse-tree information like grammatical headwords in a sentence (Charniak, 2001) (Chelba and Jelinek, 1998), or based on part of-speech (POS) tag information (Galescu and Ringger, 1999)
clean_text: In the first type, probability of a word is decided based on a parse-tree information like grammatical headwords in a sentence (Charniak, 2001) (Chelba and Jelinek, 1998), or based on part of-speech (POS) tag information (Galescu and Ringger, 1999).
